awd_titl_txt: RII Track-4: High-Throughput Phenotyping and Analysis for the Study of Plant Robustness
awd_abstract_narration:
Predicting the characteristics, or traits, and behaviors of an individual organism from its DNA sequence is proving to be a very challenging and complex problem. One complicating factor is that the connection between DNA and traits is not consistent, and identical DNA sequences may not produce identical traits even when the environment is the same. This occurs because certain genes influence how stable or variable (robust) a trait is, with some genes producing traits that are more or less variable. Therefore, the identity of the genes that influence robustness is needed to build models to predict traits from DNA sequences. This knowledge is crucial to accelerate crop breeding, to meet growing global demands for food, and provide economic security to American producers. The current bottleneck in discovering genes that control robustness in plants is the inefficient process of measuring plant traits. To address this problem, the Donald Danforth Plant Science Center in St. Louis, Missouri has built state-of-the-art facilities and developed computer programs to automatically measure the characteristics of thousands of plants. Through extensive collaborative visits, the PI and a student trainee will use these facilities and learn methods for processing this data and how to build low-cost versions of these automated systems with the intent to bring this infrastructure to Montana. This support will enable the identification of DNA sequences that influence robustness and the relationships in robustness among characteristics.

Predicting phenotypes from genotypes is proving to be challenging and complex. One complicating factor is that the relationship between genotype and phenotype is problematic. While the entire genome of an organism, rather than single alleles, determines the phenotype and degree of phenotypic variability, a poor understanding of how robustness is controlled at the molecular and cellular levels remains. This knowledge gap exists because to measure robustness for any given trait, a large number of individuals with the same genetic make-up must be measured. Therefore, the objective of this fellowship is high-throughput phenotyping at the Donald Danforth Plant Science Center for the plant Arabidopsis thaliana. In addition, this fellowship supports the comprehensive training of the PI and a trainee in high-throughput data collection and analyses. The data and skills gained will enable testing of the central hypothesis: genetics influences the robustness of traits in predictable ways. Specifically, the data will support identifying 1) genes modulating robustness (phenotypic variability) and 2) patterns of robustness throughout plant development. We expect that with extensive data from a model species, we will identify patterns that describe robustness for comparison across plant species, that include crops. These data will facilitate crop breeding, crucial to the NSF's mission of national security through its impacts on food and economic security. Furthermore, this fellowship will benefit Montana State University's research infrastructure through supporting the development of a low-cost automated phenotyping platform that can be utilized across crops bred in Montana. Further, hands-on demonstrations of automated phenotyping for plants will expose rural girls to computer science/engineering, fields in which women are traditionally underrepresented.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project focused on understanding plant robustness, which refers to how consistently individual plants recreate a trait when grown the same environment. This is particularly important when considering that we need food, fiber, and fuel crops to predictable grow sufficient yields to support supply chain security. However, our understanding of consistency is limited as it requires measuring more individuals than is standard in typical experiments. In this project, we examined plant robustness across scales, from the field-level to the molecular. The project also had a secondary focus, allowing the primary investigator to utilize the facilities and network with scientists at another institution. Therefore, the major approach in this study was to measure the degree of robustness in various plant traits. The primary method of data collection was through high-throughput phenotyping, conducted at the Donald Danforth Plant Science Center (DDPSC). The primary objective was to investigate how genetics influences the oilseed Camelina sativa (camelina). Throughout the project, we meticulously tracked the growth trajectories of 103 camelina accessions collected worldwide, employing advanced sensors for daily imaging to estimate growth trajectories and then measuring the true biomass. Our analysis of camelina growth trajectories revealed significant differences in biomass and variance across accessions, supporting the role of genetic control in driving variability in early development.

Secondarily to these primary goals, we also developed a cost-effective network of cameras controlled by Raspberry Pi computers, enabling data collection at Montana State University on a smaller scale.

Furthermore, we conducted two additional assessments of the robustness of plant traits. First, we completed a comprehensive analysis of how breeding has influenced robustness of Montana’s winter wheat by examining yield variability several decades and locations. We found no evidence winter wheat robustness has improved with breeding, suggesting new avenues for future breeding efforts. 

At the molecular level, we examined how robustness in the concentrations of cellular molecules respond to acute stresses, in several organisms, including plants. We observed more robustness in metabolites under stress conditions compared to optimal ones, which may be counterintuitive. One may expect that under stress, molecules become more dysregulated and inconsistent, but our results support otherwise.

In terms of outcomes, we provided extensive training opportunities for researchers at the graduate and undergraduate levels, fostering expertise in plant science and data science. Our results were disseminated widely through seminars, international and national conferences, and publications, reaching communities of interest, and fostering collaboration and knowledge exchange. We showcased our innovative approach to low-cost phenotyping through a live YouTube event. Moreover, our work on winter wheat and metabolite robustness has been published, contributing to the broader scientific understanding of plant robustness. In conclusion, our project has not only advanced our understanding of plant robustness but also provided valuable training and insights that will shape future research endeavors in plant science.
